response_parsed.title: Documenting CLI Tools Using FastAPI in Python 3.12+
response_parsed.summary: This guide explains how to create well-documented command-line interfaces (CLI) for your FastAPI applications using the OpenAPI 3.0 specifications and tools available in Python 3.12+.
key_points: FastAPI can be used to build CLI tools by utilizing its powerful dependency injection, routing, and OpenAPI support.
OpenAPI 3.0 provides a standardized format for API documentation, making it an ideal choice for documenting CLI tools as well.
To create a CLI tool with FastAPI, you will need to use the `uvicorn` command-line utility and create a main script to call your FastAPI app.
You can define your CLI arguments using the FastAPI `Query` and `Path` parameters annotated with appropriate types such as `str`, `int`, or even custom types for complex arguments.
Documentation for each API endpoint will automatically be included in your CLI tool's help output when the `--openapi-url` flag is provided to `uvicorn`.
To further enhance documentation, you can use tools like `swagger-ui`, `redocly`, or even generate markdown files from your OpenAPI specification.
version_notes: The examples provided in this explainer are compatible with Python 3.12+ and FastAPI version 0.70.0 or later.
Some features, such as the automatic inclusion of documentation in CLI help output, require using `uvicorn` version 0.17.0 or later.
caveats: While FastAPI is an excellent choice for building web APIs, it might not be the best fit for complex, feature-rich command-line applications due to its focus on RESTful web services.
When documenting your CLI tools with FastAPI, keep in mind that the output will primarily be text-based and may require additional formatting or organization to make it user-friendly.
